project.name: First Graph - Learning Template
project.description: An interactive graph learning experience teaching graph structures, nodes, edges, and common patterns (tree, star, DAG, cycle).

tasks.description: Learn what makes a graph: nodes (things) connected by edges (relationships). Explore the 5 core concepts: nodes, edges, direction, weight, and labels. Use the graph UI to click on each concept node and understand how they relate.

Explore the tree pattern: root ‚Üí branches ‚Üí leaves. Click on 'Tree' node, then hover to highlight Root, Branches, and Leaves. Try searching for 'Leaf' to jump between examples. Real-world use: org charts, file systems, taxonomies.

Study the star pattern: one central hub connected to many spokes. Click 'Star' node and explore Spoke 1-4. Notice how all flow through the center. Real-world use: platforms, routers, social media hubs, centralized services.

Understand DAG: directed edges flowing forward with no cycles. Click 'DAG' node and trace the path: Task A ‚Üí Task B & Task C ‚Üí Task D. Each edge shows a dependency. Real-world use: build pipelines, task scheduling, prerequisite chains.

Discover cycles: State 1 ‚Üí State 2 ‚Üí State 3 ‚Üí State 1. Click 'Cycle' and hover to see the loop close back on itself. Real-world use: control systems, iterative processes, reinforcing feedback, circular dependencies (sometimes a bug!).

Practice all UI features: (1) Hover any node to highlight neighbors. (2) Click to open details. (3) Use menu search to find 'Task D' or 'Leaf'. (4) Scroll to zoom, drag to pan. (5) Click 'Reset View' to return. Try each on different structures.

Learn how nodes have properties (layer, parent) and edges have types (HAS_SUBCATEGORY, DEVELOPS, CREATES, LEADS_TO). Click concept nodes to see how direction matters: (A ‚Üí B) is different from (A ‚Äî B). These encode meaning.

For each structure, follow its path to a use case. Tree ‚Üí Hierarchies (org charts). Star ‚Üí Hubs (platforms). DAG ‚Üí Dependencies (build systems). Cycle ‚Üí Feedback Loops (control systems). Each leads to 'Pick the Right Model'. Match your problem to the right structure.

Pick a real-world scenario (team org, build pipeline, social network, feedback loop). Identify nodes and edges. Determine structure (tree/star/DAG/cycle). Sketch it. Then explore this graph and find similar patterns to learn from.

Follow the guided tour (click 'Guided Tour' in menu) for a step-by-step walkthrough. Tour covers: start here, basics, structures, search feature, tree/DAG/cycle examples, and the decision outcome. Completes the full learning journey.
Explore the bipartite pattern: two node sets with edges only between sets. Practice matching left‚Üíright pairs and think about real-world examples: job applicants ‚Üí companies, users ‚Üí products.
Use the path example to explore edge weights and find short/long routes. Identify the most central node (highest degree) and see how centrality helps find hubs or critical nodes in networks.

graphTemplate.description: A comprehensive interactive graph teaching all graph fundamentals: nodes, edges, layers, structures (tree, star, DAG, cycle), use cases, and decision-making.

profile.title: First Graph: Learn Graphs
items: This template is intentionally small, but it demonstrates multiple graph structures using the same UI interactions.
Try: hover a node ‚Üí see neighbors; click a node ‚Üí open details; search ‚Üí focus; zoom/pan ‚Üí explore clusters.
Goal: learn how nodes/edges/layers map to real-world models (dependencies, hierarchies, hubs, feedback).

basics.title: Graph Basics
items: A graph is a set of nodes connected by edges.
In this UI: parent nodes are larger; child nodes inherit the parent color.

concept-node.title: Node (vertex)
items: A distinct thing: a person, a task, a concept, a page.

concept-edge.title: Edge (link)
items: A relationship between two nodes: depends-on, contains, leads-to, relates-to.

concept-direction.title: Directed vs undirected
items: Dependencies are usually directed (A ‚Üí B). Friendship is often undirected (A ‚Äî B).

concept-weight.title: Weight / cost
items: Edges can carry numbers (time, cost, distance). Shortest-path algorithms use weights.

concept-labels.title: Labels / types
items: Edge types let you encode meaning (e.g., HAS_SUBCATEGORY vs LEADS_TO).

interactions.title: How To Use This Graph
items: This view is interactive. Use the menu buttons and the search box.
Tip: clicking nodes is the best way to learn‚Äîevery node has a short explanation.

ui-hover.title: Hover = highlight neighbors
items: Hover a node to highlight its immediate connections.

ui-click.title: Click = open details
items: Click any node to open its details popup.

ui-search.title: Search = find & focus
items: Use the menu search to jump to a node by name or detail text.

ui-zoom.title: Zoom / pan
items: Scroll/pinch to zoom. Drag the background to pan.

ui-reset.title: Reset view
items: Use Reset View to return to the default zoom and clear highlights.

structures.title: Graph Structures
items: Below are common shapes you will see in real data: trees, stars, DAGs, cycles.
These are not different UIs‚Äîjust different node/edge patterns.

structure-tree.title: Tree (hierarchy)
items: A connected structure with no cycles. Great for categories and org charts.

tree-root.title: Root
items: The top of a hierarchy. Everything flows downward.

tree-branch-a.title: Branch A
items: A subgroup under the root.

tree-branch-b.title: Branch B
items: Another subgroup under the root.

tree-leaf-a1.title: Leaf A1
items: Leaves are terminal nodes in a tree path.

tree-leaf-b1.title: Leaf B1
items: Leaves are often the actionable / concrete items.

structure-star.title: Star (hub & spokes)
items: One central node connected to many others. Common in routing, platforms, and popularity graphs.

star-spoke-1.title: Spoke 1
items: A neighbor connected to the hub.

star-spoke-2.title: Spoke 2
items: A neighbor connected to the hub.

star-spoke-3.title: Spoke 3
items: A neighbor connected to the hub.

star-spoke-4.title: Spoke 4
items: A neighbor connected to the hub.

structure-dag.title: DAG (dependency graph)
items: A directed acyclic graph: edges point forward and there are no cycles.
Used for build pipelines, task scheduling, and prerequisites.

dag-a.title: Task A
items: A prerequisite feeding into multiple tasks.

dag-b.title: Task B
items: Depends on A.

dag-c.title: Task C
items: Also depends on A.

dag-d.title: Task D
items: Combines outputs from B and C.

structure-cycle.title: Cycle (feedback loop)
items: Cycles mean you can return to where you started.
Sometimes desired (feedback systems), sometimes a problem (circular dependencies).

cycle-1.title: State 1
items: Part of a loop.

cycle-2.title: State 2
items: Part of a loop.

cycle-3.title: State 3
items: Part of a loop.

bip-left-1.title: Bipartite Left 1
items: Left partition node. Bipartite graphs connect nodes only across partitions, useful for matching problems (applicants‚Üîjobs). Try finding match pairs.

bip-left-2.title: Bipartite Left 2
items: Left partition node.

bip-right-1.title: Bipartite Right 1
items: Right partition node.

bip-right-2.title: Bipartite Right 2
items: Right partition node.

clique-1.title: Clique A1
items: A node in a fully connected group (clique). Cliques show tight communities where everyone connects to everyone.

clique-2.title: Clique A2
items: A node in a fully connected group (clique).

clique-3.title: Clique A3
items: A node in a fully connected group (clique).

community-a-1.title: Community A1
items: Part of a dense community. Community detection groups nodes by internal connectivity.

community-a-2.title: Community A2
items: Part of a dense community.

community-b-1.title: Community B1
items: A node in a different community.

community-b-2.title: Community B2
items: A node in a different community.

path-1.title: Path Node 1
items: Start of a path used to demonstrate weighted shortest paths.

path-2.title: Path Node 2
items: Middle path node (lower weight edge here encourages shortest paths through this node).

path-3.title: Path Node 3
items: Middle path node (higher weight edge here discourages shortest path).

path-4.title: Path Node 4
items: End of path.

centrality.title: Centrality: High Degree Node
items: A node connected to many others. Centrality helps find hubs and critical infrastructure in networks.

usecase-hierarchy.title: Use Case: Hierarchies
items: Org charts, categories, file/folder trees, taxonomy.

usecase-hub.title: Use Case: Hubs
items: Platforms, routers, central services, influencer networks.

usecase-deps.title: Use Case: Dependencies
items: Task planning, build systems, prerequisites, pipelines.

usecase-feedback.title: Use Case: Feedback Loops
items: Control systems, iteration cycles, reinforcing effects.

outcome.title: Outcome: Pick the Right Model
items: If your data is hierarchical ‚Üí tree.
If you have prerequisites ‚Üí DAG.
If you have a central service ‚Üí star/hub.
If effects reinforce each other ‚Üí cycle/loop.
